questions.text: The primary lymphoid organ is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymus

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature. The primary lymphoid organs are where lymphocytes (B cells and T cells) are produced and mature. The thymus specifically is the site of T cell maturation, a crucial process for the development of the immune system.

 

The bone marrow is another primary lymphoid organ, where B cells mature.

 

Secondary lymphoid organs, in contrast, are sites where mature lymphocytes become activated in response to antigens. These include the lymph nodes, spleen, Peyer’s patches, and tonsils.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver is not considered a lymphoid organ. It plays a role in various metabolic processes, detoxification, and protein synthesis, but it is not involved in the direct maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Lymph node: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. They are involved in filtering lymph and providing a site for the interaction of lymphocytes with antigens, which helps initiate the immune response.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is also a secondary lymphoid organ. It filters blood, removes old red blood cells, and helps in the immune response by facilitating the interaction between lymphocytes and antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It plays a critical role in the development of the immune system.

questions.text: In polyarticular onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), the condition involves more than how many joints? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 5

 

Explanation:

 

Polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is defined by the involvement of 5 or more joints during the first 6 months of disease. This subtype of JIA affects approximately 25-40% of children with juvenile arthritis and can be further classified as rheumatoid factor positive or negative.

 

The classification of JIA is based on the number of joints involved in the initial 6 months:

  • Oligoarticular JIA: affects 4 or fewer joints
  • Polyarticular JIA: affects 5 or more joints
  • Systemic JIA: characterized by arthritis with systemic features including fever and rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3 - Incorrect. Involvement of 3 joints would be classified as oligoarticular JIA, which is defined as arthritis affecting 4 or fewer joints.

 

Option B. 4 - Incorrect. Involvement of 4 joints would still be classified as oligoarticular JIA.

 

Option D. 6 - Incorrect. While 6 joints would qualify as polyarticular JIA, the minimum threshold is 5 joints, not 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polyarticular JIA is defined by involvement of ≥5 joints during the first 6 months, while oligoarticular JIA involves ≤4 joints. This distinction is critical for proper classification, treatment approach, and prognostication.

questions.text: Which nerve root is primarily associated with weakness of the Extensor Hallucis Longus?(NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) L5

 

Explanation:

 

Extensor hallucis longus is primarily innervated by the L5 nerve root. This muscle belongs to the anterior compartment of the leg and is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve which has root value L4, L5, and S1. The myotome chart clearly indicates that extensor hallucis longus has a predominant L5 innervation, making weakness of this muscle a key clinical sign in L5 radiculopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L4: While L4 contributes to the deep peroneal nerve, it primarily supplies tibialis anterior and tibialis posterior. L4 is more associated with ankle dorsiflexion but not specifically with great toe extension.

 

Option C. S1: S1 primarily innervates the gastrocnemius, soleus, peronei, and extensor digitorum brevis. It's more associated with plantar flexion and foot eversion rather than great toe extension.

 

Option D. S2: S2 primarily innervates intrinsic foot muscles, flexor digitorum longus, and flexor hallucis longus. It has no significant contribution to extensor hallucis longus innervation.

 

Education Objective: 

 

L5 is the predominant nerve root for extensor hallucis longus, making great toe extension weakness a classic clinical finding in L5 radiculopathy.

choices.text: It is a type of droplet infection
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.text: All of the following are TRUE about Rubella infection, EXCEPT? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease

 

Rubella infection in the 1st trimester: 90% have a significant risk for abortion and severe congenital malformations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of droplet infection:  This statement is true. Rubella is transmitted via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vertical transmission is possible:  This statement is true. Rubella can be transmitted from the mother to the fetus.

 

Option D. Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness:  This statement is true. While the risk of severe congenital malformations is lower in late pregnancy, the fetus may still be affected, with deafness being a potential outcome.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RUBELLA

 

Cause → RNA Togavirus

 

IP → 14-21 Days

 

Source → Cases [No carriers - No Iceberg phenomenon]

 

Mode of Transmission → Resp. [Air droplets]

 

Period of Communicability → 1 week before rash ← SYMPTOMS → 1 week after rash

 

Vaccine → Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain [C/I in pregnancy]

 

1st priority group → Non pregnant Non Lactating Reproductive 15-49 yrs female [1st trimester]


Congenital Rubella Syndrome → CVD [PDA], Cataract, Sensory Neural Deafness

 

Most common and most dangerous time for transmission of Rubella from Mother to Child is First trimester

questions.text: Analyze the pedigree provided. Which mode of inheritance does it suggest? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

This pedigree shows a pattern consistent with mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Key features supporting this conclusion include:

  • Only females transmit the trait (maternal inheritance pattern).
  • All children (sons and daughters) of affected mothers are affected.
  • No children of affected fathers are affected.
  • The trait appears in every generation via the maternal line only.
  • Male-to-offspring transmission is absent, which is a hallmark of mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive – Incorrect

Autosomal recessive conditions typically show a horizontal pattern (affecting siblings rather than parent-to-child transmission). They often skip generations and require both parents to be carriers. In contrast, this pedigree shows consistent maternal transmission without generational skipping.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant – Incorrect

Autosomal dominant inheritance shows vertical transmission with equal male and female transmission, and affected fathers can pass the trait to their children. However, in this pedigree, affected males do not transmit the trait at all, which is not compatible with autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant – Incorrect

X-linked dominant inheritance shows father-to-daughter transmission (all daughters of affected fathers are affected, but sons are not). This pattern is not seen in the pedigree, and males do not transmit the condition, ruling out X-linked dominance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission only. All children of affected mothers inherit the condition, whereas no children of affected fathers are affected, due to the exclusive maternal origin of mitochondrial DNA. Both males and females may be affected, but only females pass on the trait.

questions.text: A patient with multiple skin tumors presented to OPD, further workup revealed defective DNA repair due to double strand break. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Xeroderma pigmentosum

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in nucleotide excision repair (NER), which is essential for repairing DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light. Patients with XP are unable to effectively repair DNA damage, leading to the accumulation of mutations in skin cells, particularly following exposure to UV light. This defect in DNA repair results in a high propensity for developing multiple skin tumors, including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and malignant melanoma. The key point is the "defective DNA repair due to double strand break," which directly correlates with the genetic defect seen in XP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: Although Bloom syndrome also involves a defect in DNA repair, it is more commonly associated with hematological malignancies like lymphoma and leukemia, rather than skin tumors. Patients typically present with a predisposition to developing blood-related cancers (lymphoma, leukemia) rather than solid tumors on the skin.

 

Option C. Cockayne’s syndrome: Cockayne syndrome is associated with photosensitivity and growth problems in children, but it is not associated with the development of malignancies, including skin tumors.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is primarily associated with an increased risk of colon cancer and other internal malignancies, but it is not associated with skin tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in nucleotide excision repair, leading to a high risk of developing multiple skin tumors due to the inability to repair DNA damage caused by UV light exposure.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with obesity and developmental delay. It is caused by paternal deletion and imprinted maternal allele. Which chromosome is involved? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15

 

The clinical presentation describes Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS). In PWS, chromosome 15 is involved, where under normal conditions:

 

  • The maternal allele is imprinted (inhibited)
  • Only the paternal allele is working When the paternal allele gets deleted while the maternal allele is already imprinted, both copies become non-functional, resulting in PWS. The condition affects chromosome15q11-q13 region.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Obesity
  • Developmental delay
  • Hypotonia (low muscle tone) in infancy
  • Hyperphagia (excessive eating) leading to obesity
  • Mild to moderate intellectual disability
  • Short stature and small hands and feet
  • Hypogonadism (underdeveloped genitals and delayed puberty)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 21: Incorrect

 

  • Chromosome 21 is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21)
  • Not involved in genomic imprinting disorders

 

Option B. Chromosome 11: Incorrect

 

  • While chromosome 11 shows genomic imprinting in some cases (like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome), it's not associated with Symptoms mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Chromosome 10: Incorrect

 

  • Chromosome 10 is not associated with major genomic imprinting disorders
  • Not involved in PWS or Angelman syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi Syndrome involves chromosome 15, specifically:

 

  • Maternal allele is imprinted (naturally inhibited)
  • Paternal allele deletion
  • Results in both copies being non-functional

 

For remembering deletion pattern: 

 

"PAPA deleted in PWS"

 

Paternal deletion in Prader-Willi Syndrome

 

"Mothers are Angels"

 

Angelman syndrome = Maternal deletion

questions.text: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures of anthropometry? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight-for-height

 

Wasting in a child is an indicator of acute malnutrition and is assessed using the weight-for-height measure. This metric evaluates whether a child’s weight is appropriate for their height, which reflects their current nutritional status. Wasting indicates that a child has lost weight rapidly in relation to their height, usually due to insufficient nutrient intake or disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight-for-age: This measure is used to assess whether a child is underweight, which is an acute on chronic malnutrition.

 

Option C. Height-for-age: This measure is used to assess stunting, which indicates chronic malnutrition. Stunting reflects a long-term deficiency in nutrition, resulting in reduced growth in height.

 

Option D. Height-for-weight: This option is not a standard anthropometric measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wasting in a child is assessed using the weight-for-height measure, indicating acute malnutrition

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with disproportionate short stature with increased upper segment: lower segment ratio. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is characterized by an increased upper segment to lower segment ratio. Normal US:LS ratio values are:

 

  • At birth: 1.7:1
  • At 3 years: 1.3:1
  • At 7-10 years: 1:1

 

When this ratio is increased, remember the mnemonic RHA:

 

  • R: Rickets
  • H: Hypothyroidism
  • A: Achondroplasia

 

In achondroplasia, FGFR3 gene mutation leads to:

 

  • Short limbed dwarfism with proximal limb shortening
  • Trident hand
  • Motor milestones delayed
  • Large head
  • Obesity
  • Decreased interpedicular distance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia: Incorrect. This primarily affects spine and epiphyses causing short trunk dwarfism, not increased US:LS ratio.

 

Option C. Alagille syndrome: Incorrect. Features butterfly vertebrae, peripheral pulmonary stenosis and bile duct paucity, but doesn't affect US:LS ratio.

 

Option D. TB spine: Incorrect. Causes vertebral destruction and gibbus deformity but doesn't characteristically alter US:LS ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia presents with an increased upper segment:lower segment ratio due to short limbs with a relatively preserved trunk length. The condition is caused by an FGFR3 gene mutation and is the most common form of disproportionate short stature.

questions.text: Where are stereocilia located? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Hair cells

 

Explanation:

 

Stereocilia are specialized microvilli-like projections found on the apical surface of hair cells in the inner ear. These projections (30-150 per cell) have cores composed of parallel filaments of actin. Stereocilia are mechanosensitive structures essential for transduction of sound and balance information in the cochlea and vestibular apparatus.

Visual Support: In the inner ear, hair cells have one large kinocilium (true cilium) and multiple stereocilia arranged in a distinctive pattern where they increase progressively in height toward the kinocilium. When these stereocilia are deflected by fluid movement, tip links connecting adjacent stereocilia open mechanically-sensitive cation channels, initiating sensory transduction.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Taste buds - Taste receptor cells have microvilli (not stereocilia) that project into the taste pore where they contact tastants dissolved in saliva.
  • Option c. Retina - The retina contains photoreceptors (rods and cones) with specialized outer segments containing discs of membrane with photopigments, but these are not stereocilia.
  • Option d. Nose - Olfactory sensory neurons possess cilia (not stereocilia) that extend into the mucus layer where they bind odorant molecules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stereocilia are unique actin-rich projections found exclusively on hair cells of the inner ear that function as mechanosensitive structures essential for hearing and vestibular function.

questions.text: 15-year-old girl with wide-spaced nipples, short height, and the following karyotype: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome


Turner syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome (45, X) rather than the typical two sex chromosomes (XX or XY). The karyotype shown confirms the absence of the Y chromosome and only one X chromosome, which is diagnostic of Turner syndrome. Clinical features often include short stature, wide-spaced nipples, webbed neck, and other physical anomalies. Turner syndrome is a common genetic condition tested in exams due to its distinctive features and significant clinical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY). It does not fit the description of a 15-year-old girl with the specific karyotype shown and is not associated with the physical characteristics described.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21 (an extra chromosome 21) and typically presents with distinct facial features, intellectual disability, and other health issues. The karyotype shown does not match Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Partial mole: A partial mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease involving an abnormal pregnancy with an extra set of paternal chromosomes, often presenting with symptoms related to pregnancy and abnormal placental tissue rather than the clinical features described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Turner syndrome is characterized by the karyotype 45,X, and typical clinical features include short stature and wide-spaced nipples, commonly seen in females.

questions.text: How many intrinsic muscles of the hand are supplied by the ulnar nerve? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. 15

 

Explanation:

 

The ulnar nerve supplies 15 intrinsic muscles of the hand. These include all hypothenar muscles (abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi), the palmaris brevis, all four palmar interossei, all four dorsal interossei, the adductor pollicis, and the deep head of flexor pollicis brevis (sometimes). The ulnar nerve is known as the "musician's nerve" because it controls fine movements of the fingers through its extensive motor distribution to these short muscles of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. 5 - This is incorrect. The median nerve supplies 5 muscles in the hand (thenar muscles - abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the first and second lumbricals).
  • Option B. 13 - This is incorrect. The number of intrinsic hand muscles supplied by the ulnar nerve is 15, not 13.
  • Option D. 17 - This is incorrect. The total number of intrinsic muscles in the hand is 20, of which 15 are supplied by the ulnar nerve and 5 by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The ulnar nerve supplies 15 out of the 20 intrinsic muscles of the hand, making it the primary motor nerve of the hand and earning it the title of "musician's nerve" for its role in fine motor control of the fingers.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Anencephaly

 

The ultrasound image shows the absence of cranial bones, which are typically visible as white structures on ultrasound. In anencephaly, the forebrain and cranial vault are absent, resulting in a recognizable appearance on ultrasound. Additionally, anencephaly is often associated with prominent eyeballs, known as the "frog eye sign," further supporting this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: This condition presents as a fluid-filled cystic mass, often seen in the neck region. On ultrasound, cystic hygroma appears as a black (anechoic) structure due to its fluid content, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: Encephalocele is characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull, usually seen as a sac-like protrusion. This appearance is distinct from anencephaly and involves brain tissue extending outside the cranial cavity, which is not observed here.

 

Option D. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition involves an enlarged posterior fossa with a cystic structure, indicating the presence of a posterior fossa cyst. The ultrasound findings of Dandy Walker malformation are distinct and do not match the current image showing an absence of cranial bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is diagnosed by the absence of cranial bones and brain tissue on ultrasound, often accompanied by the "frog eye sign."

questions.text: What is the germ layer origin of the epithelium of the urinary bladder? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) Endoderm

 

Explanation:

 

The epithelium of the urinary bladder is derived from endoderm. The urinary bladder develops from the urogenital sinus, which forms after the cloaca is divided by the urorectal septum into a dorsal anorectal canal and a ventral urogenital sinus. The urogenital sinus is lined by endoderm. As development continues, the upper portion of the urogenital sinus expands to form the urinary bladder, while the lower portion forms the urethra. The endodermal lining of the urogenital sinus differentiates into the transitional epithelium (urothelium) that lines the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Ectoderm - This is incorrect because ectoderm gives rise to the epidermis, nervous system, and various specialized structures like hair, nails, and tooth enamel. It does not contribute to the urinary bladder epithelium.

 

Option b) Mesoderm - This is incorrect because although mesoderm forms the muscular wall (detrusor muscle) and connective tissue of the urinary bladder, it does not form the epithelial lining. Mesoderm forms the middle layer of the trilaminar embryonic disc and gives rise to muscle, bone, connective tissue, kidneys, and gonads.

 

Option d) Neuroectoderm - This is incorrect because neuroectoderm, a specialized portion of ectoderm, forms the neural tube and neural crest cells. It gives rise to the central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, and various neural crest derivatives, but not to the epithelium of the urinary bladder.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The epithelium of the urinary bladder derives from endoderm of the urogenital sinus, while its muscular and connective tissue components are mesodermal in origin, demonstrating how different germ layers contribute to the formation of a single organ.

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns following which the surgical procedure was done as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the likely procedure done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiersch skin graft

 

The image shows a meshed graft, which is characteristic of a Thiersch skin graft, also known as a split-thickness skin graft (STSG). This type of graft involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site, which includes the epidermis and part of the dermis. The meshing process creates perforations in the graft, increasing its surface area and allowing exudates to escape, which facilitates healing. Meshing also helps the graft to cover a larger area, which is particularly useful in cases of extensive burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Full thickness skin graft: This involves transplanting the entire thickness of the skin (epidermis and entire dermis). These grafts are typically used for areas requiring better cosmetic outcomes, such as the face, and are not usually meshed.

 

Option C. Biological mesh: This is used in various surgical repairs, such as hernias, and involves biological material to reinforce or replace tissue. It is not typically used for skin grafting in burns.

 

Option D. Artificial membrane: This refers to synthetic or biologically engineered membranes used to cover wounds or burns. The image shows a skin graft rather than an artificial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A meshed appearance on a graft used for burn treatment indicates a Thiersch skin graft (split-thickness skin graft), which is designed to cover a larger area and facilitate exudate drainage.

questions.text: Myxoedema Madness most frequently presents as: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Auditory Hallucination and Paranoia

 

Explanation:

 

In its most severe form, myxedema madness a term describing the psychiatric manifestation of severe hypothyroidism can present with a range of symptoms, including paranoia, depression, hypomania, and hallucinations. Auditory hallucinations are the most common form in psychiatric conditions generally, making auditory hallucination plus paranoia the most characteristic presentation in this context.

This combination can closely mimic paranoid psychosis or schizophrenia, particularly in elderly women with undiagnosed hypothyroidism. The pathophysiology involves thyroid hormone deficiency leading to widespread alterations in neurotransmitter balance, cerebral metabolism, and cognitive function, producing a full spectrum of mood and psychotic symptoms.

 

 Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Visual Hallucination and Depression: While depression is commonly associated with hypothyroidism, visual hallucinations are less typical features in myxedema madness. Auditory hallucinations remain the most likely type when psychosis occurs.
  • Option C. Tactile Hallucination and Paranoia: Tactile hallucinations are more characteristic of substance-induced psychosis, such as that caused by stimulants (e.g., cocaine or methamphetamine), and are not commonly linked to hypothyroid states.
  • Option D. Paranoia and Depression: Both symptoms are indeed noted in myxedema madness, but this option omits hallucinations, which are part of the more complete and classic presentation in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:


Myxedema madness presents with a constellation of psychiatric symptoms, most characteristically paranoia with hallucinations (typically auditory), sometimes alongside depression and hypomania. Always consider hypothyroidism in cases of new-onset psychosis in older adults, especially when accompanied by physical signs like cold intolerance, bradycardia, dry skin, and weight gain.

questions.text: How will you collect samples for blood culture in a patient with suspected Infective Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 aerobic and 3 anaerobic

 

Explanation:

 

Infective endocarditis is diagnosed using Duke's criteria, which includes major and minor criteria. One of the major criteria involves positive blood cultures.

 

For accurate diagnosis, it is essential to collect multiple blood cultures to identify the causative organism reliably.

 

A blood culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

According to Duke's criteria:

 

  • A minimum of two cultures should be drawn at least 12 hours apart.
  • Ideally, three or more cultures should be collected.
  • When collecting three or more cultures, each culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

Therefore, for three culture sets, you would collect three aerobic and three anaerobic samples.

 

The rules for collection are:

 

  1. If two culture sets are collected, both should be drawn at least 12 hours apart and both should be positive.
  2. If three or more culture sets are collected, all three should be positive for the same organism.
  3. If more than three culture sets are collected, the majority should be positive for the same organism.
  4. The gap between the first and the last culture should be at least one hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected infective endocarditis, the recommended blood culture collection includes three aerobic and three anaerobic samples to ensure accurate diagnosis and identification of the causative organism

questions.text: According to KDIGO staging of chronic kidney disease (CKD), what is the GFR range for stage 3b? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²

 

Stage 3b CKD is defined by a GFR range of 30–44 mL/min/1.73m². CKD stage 3 is divided into two subcategories:

 

  • Stage 3a: GFR 45–59 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3b: GFR 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²

 

Educational Objective:

 

GFR ranges for CKD staging:

 

  • Stage 1: >90 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 2: 60–89 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3a: 45–59 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3b: 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 4: 15–29 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 5: <15 mL/min/1.73m²

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

 

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection

 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HS, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Incorrect, as Rabies is associated with Negri bodies, which are specific cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Incorrect, as this condition is linked to Henderson-Peterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Incorrect for Cowdry Type A inclusions; however, Cowdry type C basophilic inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus is the predominant fungal pathogen linked with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, underscoring the critical need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment in such high-risk groups to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy


The patient is a 45-year-old woman presenting with cervical erosion and spotting, which raises a concern for potential cervical cancer. In such cases, the next best step involves a comprehensive approach to screen for cervical cancer:

 

  1. Liquid-based cytology (LBC): This test is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  2. HPV testing: This helps identify high-risk human papillomavirus strains that are associated with cervical cancer.
  3. Cervical biopsy: If any abnormalities are found on cytology or HPV testing, a cervical biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Performing all three tests together provides a thorough evaluation, as cervical cancer screening is essential in women presenting with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pap smear + HCV: While a Pap smear is appropriate for screening, HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) testing is unrelated to the current presentation of cervical symptoms.

 

Option C. Pap smear + HBV: Similar to option B, the Pap smear is correct, but testing for HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) does not address the concern for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. VDRL + HBV: VDRL is used for syphilis screening and is not relevant to cervical erosion and spotting, nor is HBV testing in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

questions.text: Mt. Fuji sign is seen in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocephalus

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is a radiological sign seen in cases of tension pneumocephalus. Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air within the cranial cavity. This condition often arises due to trauma, surgical procedures, or infections that introduce air into the intracranial space. The Mt. Fuji sign specifically indicates tension pneumocephalus, where the accumulated air exerts pressure on the brain structures.

 

 

In the Mt. Fuji sign, the frontal lobes of the brain appear to peak sharply, resembling the shape of Mount Fuji. This appearance is due to the air pressure causing the brain to be compressed and elevated at specific points. This sign is crucial for diagnosing tension pneumocephalus because it suggests that the brain is under significant pressure, which can lead to severe complications if not promptly addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumomediastinum: This condition involves the presence of air in the mediastinum. It is not associated with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, typically due to gastrointestinal perforation or surgical procedures. It does not present with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: This condition involves the presence of air in the pleural cavity, causing lung collapse. It is unrelated to the Mt. Fuji sign seen in pneumocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is indicative of tension pneumocephalus and is characterized by the peaking of the frontal lobes due to intracranial air pressure.

choices.text: ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67
ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67
ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with Luminal A type of breast carcinoma. Which of the following best describes the marker profile in her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+, PR+, HER2- Low Ki67

 

  • Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by hormone receptor positivity and low proliferation rates. The expression profile typically includes estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Additionally, this subtype is marked by a low Ki67 index, indicating a lower proliferation rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER+, PR+, HER2- High Ki67: This combination, while similar in hormone receptor status, features a high Ki67 index, suggestive of a more aggressive subtype like Luminal B cancer.

 

Option C. ER+, PR+, HER2+ High Ki67: This profile describes a HER2-positive and high-proliferation subtype (often seen in more aggressive breast cancers).

 

Option D. ER-, PR-, HER2- High Ki67: Known as triple-negative breast cancer, this profile is markedly different from Luminal A as it lacks expression of ER, PR, and HER2, and is associated with higher grade tumors.

 

Educational objective:

 

Luminal A breast carcinoma is characterized by positive hormone receptors (ER and PR), absence of HER2 expression, and low Ki67 levels, indicative of a slower-growing, less aggressive tumor that typically has a better prognosis compared to other subtypes.

questions.text: An inguinal hernia with acute appendicitis occurring in the sac is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amyand’s Hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically defined as an inguinal hernia where the content is the appendix. When the appendix becomes inflamed within the hernia sac, it represents a case of acute appendicitis occurring within an Amyand's hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Richter's Hernia: This occurs when only part of the bowel wall circumference is the content of the hernia. It typically doesn't present with intestinal obstruction but can directly progress to strangulation.
  • Option B. Littre's Hernia: This is defined as a hernia where the content is Meckel's diverticulum, not the appendix.
  • Option D. Maydl's Hernia: This refers to a double loop of intestine within the hernia sac.

 

Named Hernias at a glance:

  1. Omentocele - Content is omentum
  2. Enterocele - Content is intestine
  3. Richter's - Part of bowel wall circumference is in the sac
  4. Littre's - Content is Meckel's diverticulum
  5. Maydl's - Double loop of intestine
  6. Amyand's - Content is appendix
  7. Sliding hernia - Organs like cecum (right) or sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and form a part of the wall of the sac

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically an inguinal hernia containing the appendix, regardless of whether the appendix is inflamed or normal.

questions.text: Which muscle segments the axillary artery into three distinct parts? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Pectoralis minor

 

Explanation:

 

The pectoralis minor muscle divides the axillary artery into three parts as the artery passes through the axilla. The first part extends from the outer border of the first rib to the upper border of pectoralis minor. The second part lies posterior (deep) to the pectoralis minor muscle. The third part extends from the lower border of pectoralis minor to the lower border of teres major muscle, where the axillary artery continues as the brachial artery. This relationship is clinically important for describing branches of the axillary artery and for surgical approaches to the axilla.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoralis major: This larger muscle forms part of the anterior wall of the axilla but does not divide the axillary artery into segments. It overlies the pectoralis minor and forms the anterior axillary fold.

 

Option C. Serratus anterior: This muscle forms the medial wall of the axilla and has no direct relationship with segmentation of the axillary artery. It originates from the upper ribs and inserts on the medial border of the scapula.

 

 

Option D. Scalenus anticus: This is a neck muscle that divides the subclavian artery into three parts, not the axillary artery. The subclavian artery becomes the axillary artery at the outer border of the first rib.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The pectoralis minor muscle serves as an important anatomical landmark that divides the axillary artery into three parts, which helps in describing the branches of the axillary artery systematically.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the correct dose in the treatment of multibacillary leprosy in adults? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin 450 mg weekly

 

Explanation:

 

The correct treatment regimen for multibacillary leprosy in adults consists of three drugs: rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone. The standard WHO recommended regimen includes 

 

Rifampicin 600 mg given once monthly under supervision. This is combined with clofazimine 300 mg once monthly (supervised) and clofazimine 50 mg daily (unsupervised) along with dapsone 100 mg daily (unsupervised). The treatment for multibacillary leprosy is continued for 12 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy

 

 

Above regimen is given for

 

  • 12 months in multi-bacillary leprosy
  • 6 months in pauci-bacillary leprosy

choices.text: Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA)
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a condition commonly seen in diabetes patients with high blood sugar levels (RBS: 450 mg/dL). The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are characteristic of DKA.

 

The laboratory values indicate a metabolic acidosis:

 

  • pH of 7.34: Slightly acidic, indicating acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate of 12 mmol/L: Low, consistent with metabolic acidosis.
  • Chloride of 92 mmol/L: Lower than normal.

 

To determine the type of metabolic acidosis, we calculate the anion gap:

 

 

An anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L indicates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). In this case, the anion gap is 31, confirming HAGMA. 

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is typically associated with conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, renal failure, and ingestion of toxins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA): This occurs when the anion gap is normal (less than 12 mmol/L). Conditions that cause NAGMA include diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. This does not match the patient's high anion gap.

 

Option C. Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis: This condition involves an elevated pH with high bicarbonate levels. The patient’s pH is acidic, not alkalotic, and bicarbonate is low.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Characterized by a primary increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels leading to a low pH. The patient’s primary disturbance is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Na+ I- Symporter

questions.text: Identify the transporter of iodine from follicular cells to follicular cavity within the thyroid gland: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pendrin

 

The transport of iodine within the thyroid gland involves multiple steps, with specific transporters playing distinct roles. The sodium-iodide symporter (Na+ I- Symporter) is responsible for transporting iodine from the bloodstream into the thyroid follicular cells. However, once inside the follicular cells, iodine needs to be transported into the follicular cavity (colloid) where thyroid hormone synthesis occurs. This specific transport is carried out by the protein Pendrin, a chloride-iodide transporter. Pendrin moves iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid, facilitating the next steps of thyroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ I- Symporter: This symporter is involved in the initial uptake of iodine from the bloodstream into the follicular cells, not in the transport of iodine into the colloid.

 

Option C. Calmodulin: Calmodulin is a calcium-binding messenger protein, and it does not play a direct role in the transport of iodine within the thyroid gland.

 

Option D. Claudin: Claudin proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions in cells and do not have a role in the transport of iodine for thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pendrin is the transporter responsible for moving iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid of the thyroid gland, a crucial step in thyroid hormone production.

choices.text: Crude birth rate – Crude death rate
Crude birth rate + Crude death rate
Crude birth rate / Crude death rate
Crude birth rate × Crude death rate

questions.text: What is Demographic gap? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Crude birth rate – Crude death rate

 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate. It essentially measures the net increase in the population, referred to as the growth rate.

 

In demographic terms:

 

  • A positive demographic gap indicates that the birth rate is higher than the death rate, leading to population growth.
  • A negative demographic gap indicates a declining population when the death rate exceeds the birth rate.

 

The demographic gap is minimal during the early and late stages of the demographic transition model (Stages 1 and 4), where birth and death rates are balanced or declining. It peaks during Stage 2 when the birth rate remains high but the death rate drops significantly. In Stage 3, the gap starts to contract as birth rates begin to fall, and in Stage 5, it can become negative as populations age and birth rates fall below death rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The demographic gap is defined as the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate, representing the population growth rate

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness. The resting pulse was 110 beats per minute. Which of the following tests should be done next to evaluate her condition further? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TSH

 

Explanation:

 

In the evaluation of suspected thyroid dysfunction, the initial and most crucial test is the measurement of Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH). TSH is the most sensitive indicator of thyroid function because even minor changes in thyroid hormone levels cause significant changes in TSH levels due to the feedback mechanism between the thyroid gland and the pituitary gland. Elevated or suppressed TSH levels provide clear insight into whether the thyroid gland is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). Given the patient's symptoms of weight loss, anxiety, tachycardia, and restlessness, hyperthyroidism is suspected, making TSH the appropriate initial test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Total T3: T3 levels can be influenced by various factors and are usually measured after initial TSH and Free T4 tests suggest hyperthyroidism.

 

Option B.  Thyroid Scan: This imaging test evaluates thyroid structure and function, useful in cases where nodules or hyperactivity need to be assessed. It is not the first-line test for evaluating general thyroid function.

 

Option C. Free T4: Free T4 is important in assessing thyroid function and is typically measured alongside TSH. However, TSH is preferred as the initial screening test due to its sensitivity in detecting thyroid dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial test for evaluating suspected thyroid dysfunction, particularly in hyperthyroid symptoms, is TSH due to its sensitivity and reliability in reflecting thyroid status.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. Upon further investigation, arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following: pH: 7.55, PCO2: 50 mmHg, HCO3-: 44 mmol/L. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

The ABG analysis reveals a pH of 7.55, indicating alkalosis (normal pH range: 7.35-7.45). The elevated bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 44 mmol/L (normal range: 22-28 mmol/L) points towards a metabolic origin for the alkalosis. In metabolic alkalosis, the kidneys retain bicarbonate, leading to an increase in serum bicarbonate levels.

 

Additionally, the elevated PCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) of 50 mmHg (normal range: 35-45 mmHg) indicates a compensatory respiratory response. In metabolic alkalosis, the body attempts to compensate by hypoventilation, which increases PCO2 to counteract the rise in pH.

 

  • pH 7.55: Indicates alkalosis.
  • PCO2 50 mmHg: Elevated, indicating respiratory compensation.
  • HCO3- 44 mmol/L: Elevated, indicating a metabolic cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory Acidosis: This condition is characterized by a low pH and high PCO2 due to impaired ventilation, resulting in CO2 retention. The pH would be acidic, not alkalotic.

 

Option B. Respiratory Alkalosis: This condition involves a high pH and low PCO2 due to hyperventilation. However, in this case, PCO2 is elevated, not decreased.

 

Option C. Metabolic Acidosis: This condition involves a low pH and low bicarbonate levels due to an accumulation of acid or loss of bicarbonate. The pH here is alkalotic, not acidic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an elevated pH and bicarbonate level, with respiratory compensation leading to increased PCO2.

choices.text: Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

 

In a patient with severe COVID-19 who was on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs is, thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli.

 

COVID-19 is known to cause severe respiratory illness, and in severe cases, patients may require mechanical ventilation. One of the characteristic features of severe COVID-19 pneumonia is the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, including the accumulation of fibrin-rich hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. This can result in the formation of a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

 

While acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage, perivascular cuffing, and pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance may be seen in other respiratory diseases, they are not typically associated with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage: This may be seen in conditions like vasculitis or certain types of pneumonia but is not a hallmark of severe COVID-19.

 

Option C. Perivascular cuffing: This refers to lymphocytic infiltration around blood vessels and is more common in viral myocarditis and certain chronic lung diseases.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance: This is typically associated with chronic pulmonary hypertension and not an immediate feature of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

questions.text:
Consider the following Statements? [INICET NOV 2023]

 

  • Statement 1- Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
  • Statement 2- Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health
  • Statement 3- Maintenance phase/determination phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
  • Statement 4- Action phase – A person with obesity says he cant’s do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

1. Contemplation: A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking. This statement correctly aligns with the contemplation phase where an individual acknowledges the problem and begins to think seriously about solving it soon but hasn’t committed to action yet.

 

3. Maintenance phase/determination phase: A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then. This is an accurate description of the maintenance phase, where the individual has made significant changes and is focused on maintaining these changes long-term. The use of "determination phase" here is non-standard; typically, it is just called "maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Precontemplation: A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health. This statement is incorrect for this phase. The precontemplation phase is characterized by a lack of awareness or denial of the problem, not considering changes. The correct description would be not considering the benefits or need for exercise.

 

4. Action phase: A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family. This statement incorrectly describes the action phase. The action phase involves active modification of behavior. This description instead suggests resignation or justification for inaction, which could fit the precontemplation or contemplation phase but is misaligned with the proactive nature of the action phase.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Behavior change – 6 stages –

 

Precontemplation → Contemplation → Preparation/ Determination → Action/will power → Maintenance → Termination

questions.text: MgSO₄ toxicity: all are monitored except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Routine serum Mg level


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is commonly used in obstetrics to prevent seizures in preeclampsia. Monitoring for toxicity is crucial, and the primary clinical parameters to monitor include respiratory rate (RR), urine output, and deep tendon reflexes (DTR). A decrease in these parameters can indicate magnesium toxicity. Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels is not standard practice unless clinical signs of toxicity are present or there is concern based on monitored parameters. Serum levels are checked only if there is clinical suspicion of toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RR (Respiratory Rate): Monitoring respiratory rate is critical because respiratory depression is one of the first signs of magnesium toxicity. A rate below 12 breaths per minute can indicate toxicity and necessitates intervention.

 

Option B. Urine output: Urine output is monitored because reduced kidney function can lead to magnesium accumulation and toxicity. An output of less than 30 mL/hour suggests the need for caution and potential dose adjustment.

 

Option C. DTR (Deep Tendon Reflexes): DTRs are closely monitored as they are among the first clinical signs to diminish with rising magnesium levels. Loss of reflexes indicates that magnesium levels are dangerously high.

 

Educational Objective:


Routine serum magnesium levels are not typically monitored during magnesium sulfate therapy unless clinical signs of toxicity are present.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a legal rule concerning the criminal responsibility of the insane? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Haase's Rule).

 

Explanation:

 

Haase's Rule is not a legal rule concerning criminal responsibility of the insane. The established legal rules for determining criminal responsibility in cases of mental illness include the McNaughten's Rule (the "Right or Wrong test"), Durham's Rule, and Curren's Rule - all of which evaluate different aspects of a person's mental capacity at the time of committing an offense.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. McNaughten's Rule - This is a valid legal rule developed in 1843 after the Daniel McNaughten case. It states that a person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, due to mental disease, they did not know the nature of the act or that it was wrong.
  • Option B. Durham's Rule - This is a valid legal rule established in 1954 that states an accused is not criminally responsible if the unlawful act is a product of mental disease or defect.
  • Option C. Curren's Rule - This is a valid legal rule from 1964 stating that an accused is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the act, they lacked capacity to conform their conduct to legal requirements due to mental disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The assessment of criminal responsibility in cases involving mental illness relies on established legal rules that evaluate different aspects of mental capacity, with Section 84 IPC in India being primarily based on the principles of McNaughten's Rule.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elastic cartilage

 

The image shows elastic cartilage, characterized by:

 

  • More loosely arranged chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing fine elastic fibers (appearing as thin branching lines)
  • Less ground substance compared to hyaline cartilage
  • Multiple nuclei visible in each lacuna
  • The elastic fibers provide flexibility while maintaining shape
  • Found in structures like ear pinna, epiglottis, and parts of the larynx

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyaline cartilage: Incorrect because hyaline cartilage has a more homogeneous glassy matrix without visible fibers and more regularly arranged chondrocytes.

 

Option C. Fibrocartilage: Incorrect because fibrocartilage shows dense parallel bundles of collagen fibers with chondrocytes arranged in rows between them, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Articular cartilage: Incorrect because articular cartilage is a type of hyaline cartilage found at joint surfaces. The histological features shown here are characteristic of elastic cartilage, not articular cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elastic cartilage is identified by the presence of elastic fibers within its matrix, which provides flexibility and strength. It is found in the pinna of the ear, epiglottis, and Eustachian tube.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

questions.text: What is the sign shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double target sign

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the double target sign (also called target sign, halo sign, or double ring sign) which is seen in CSF rhinorrhoea. It is characterized by:

 

  • A central red spot (blood)
  • Surrounded by a peripheral halo (CSF)
  • This pattern appears when CSF mixed with blood drips onto filter paper or cloth
  • Commonly seen in traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea where blood is mixed with cerebrospinal fluid

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Radiological finding seen in blow-out fractures of orbit
  • Not related to CSF rhinorrhea

 

 

Option C. Beta 2 transferrin sign

 

  • This is not a visual sign but a laboratory test
  • Used to confirm the presence of CSF in nasal discharge
  • Tests for beta 2 transferrin which is specific to CSF

 

Option D. Handkerchief sign

 

  • Test where nasal discharge is placed on handkerchief
  • CSF doesn't stiffen the handkerchief while mucus does
  • Used to differentiate CSF from nasal mucus

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF Rhinorrhea

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

 

After stent placement, it is crucial to prevent stent thrombosis, which can be life-threatening. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is the standard of care in this scenario. DAPT includes aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor). These medications work synergistically to inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent thrombus formation within the stent.

 

The patient is already on aspirin 75 mg daily, so the addition of a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is necessary to complete the DAPT regimen. This combination has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of stent thrombosis and other cardiovascular events after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.

 

Guidelines on the duration of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) –

 

  • Drug-Eluting Stents (DES): A minimum of 6 months of DAPT is recommended. This therapy usually involves the use of aspirin combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) to prevent clot formation around the new stent.
  • Bare Metal Stents (BMS): At least 1 month of DAPT is required. Although the duration is shorter than that for DES, it's crucial for preventing early stent thrombosis.
  • Stents Inserted for Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): If a stent is inserted as part of treatment for ACS, the recommended minimum duration of DAPT extends to 12 months. This extended period helps manage the higher risk of thrombosis and other complications associated with ACS.
  • Current Patient Situation: Ongoing Medication: The patient is already on aspirin. A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor needs to be added to the regimen to complete the DAPT, ensuring optimal protection against clotting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase Aspirin dose: Increasing the aspirin dose does not provide additional benefit in preventing stent thrombosis and is not recommended as part of DAPT. The current dose of 75 mg is adequate when combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor.

 

Option B. Increase atenolol dose: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is used for managing hypertension and angina but does not prevent stent thrombosis. Increasing its dose does not address the immediate need for antiplatelet therapy post-stent placement.

 

Option C. Add a Long-Acting Nitrate: Long-acting nitrates can help manage angina symptoms but do not prevent stent thrombosis. They are not part of the recommended therapy to prevent thrombotic complications after stent placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: What is the SI unit used to measure the brightness of light from a point source among the options provided? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Candela

 

The candela is the SI unit used to measure the brightness (luminous intensity) of a light source emitting light in a specific direction. It quantifies the amount of light emitted from a point source within a solid angle of one steradian.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lux: Usage: Measures illumination or illuminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light reaching a surface. One lux is equal to one lumen per square meter.

 

Option C. Lambert: Usage: Measures brightness or luminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light emitted by a surface. One lambert is equal to the luminance of a surface emitting or reflecting one lumen per square centimeter.

 

Option D. Lumen: Usage: Measures luminous flux.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the total amount of visible light emitted by a source. One lumen is the luminous flux emitted within a solid angle of one steradian by a point source with a luminous intensity of one candela.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increased Amino acids
Raised glucose

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus comes with dizziness. Which of the following would be seen in a patient with hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fatty acid synthesis

 

Explanation:  

 

Hyperinsulinemia refers to an elevated level of insulin in the blood.

 

Insulin is a lipogenic hormone, meaning it promotes the synthesis of fatty acids and their storage as triglycerides in adipose tissue. This is due to insulin's ability to activate enzymes involved in lipogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper-ketonemia: Incorrect. Insulin suppresses ketone production, so hyperinsulinemia would prevent the formation of ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Increased Amino acids: Incorrect. Insulin promotes protein synthesis and reduces the level of amino acids in the blood by enhancing their uptake into cells and their incorporation into proteins.

 

Option C. Raised glucose: Incorrect. Hyperinsulinemia lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and inhibiting gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperinsulinemia promotes increased fatty acid synthesis due to insulin's role as a lipogenic hormone, which enhances the storage of energy in the form of fat.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

Explanation:

 

  • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. 
  • It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-Control Study: This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.

 

Option C. Ecological Study: These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.

 

Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: Which hormone is involved in the given scenario shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxytocin

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows breastfeeding, which involves the milk ejection/letdown reflex mediated by oxytocin. This is a positive feedback mechanism where suckling stimulates the release of oxytocin. milk letdown reflex is one of the classic examples of positive feedback mechanisms in the body (along with other "HCLAMP" mechanisms - Hodgkin's cycle, Clotting cascade, LH surge, Activation of digestive enzymes, Milk letdown, and Parturition reflex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline: Incorrect because adrenaline is a stress hormone released from adrenal medulla. It has no direct role in milk ejection/breastfeeding.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Incorrect because cortisol is a glucocorticoid involved in stress response and metabolism. While it may be present during breastfeeding, it is not the primary hormone responsible for milk ejection.

 

Option D. Thyroxin: Incorrect because thyroxine is involved in metabolism and growth. While it plays a supportive role in lactation by maintaining metabolic rate, it is not directly responsible for milk ejection during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is the key hormone responsible for milk ejection/letdown reflex during breastfeeding through a positive feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Which protein is responsible for connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines within a myofibril? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Titin

 

Explanation:

 

Titin is the largest known protein in the human body with a molecular mass of approximately 3,000,000 Da. It plays a critical structural role in the sarcomere by connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines, thereby providing essential scaffolding for the entire sarcomeric structure. Titin also contributes significantly to muscle elasticity through its folded domains that can unfold during initial stretching (providing low resistance) and then offer increasing resistance with further stretch to protect sarcomere integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Kinin: Kinins are inflammatory mediators and not structural proteins of muscle fibers. They have no role in connecting sarcomeric components.
  • Option b. Desmin: While desmin is an important structural protein, it functions by adding structure to the Z-lines through binding them to the plasma membrane. It does not connect Z-lines to M-lines.
  • Option d. Actin: Actin forms the thin filaments of the sarcomere and does not serve as a connecting protein between Z-lines and M-lines. It interacts with myosin during muscle contraction but does not have a structural scaffolding role between these components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Titin functions as a molecular spring providing both elasticity and structural integrity to the sarcomere by forming a continuous filament from Z-line to M-line, making it essential for proper muscle function and sarcomere stability.

questions.text: Which contrast agent is safe in a patient with renal failure? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG contrast agents

 

Ultrasound (USG) contrast agents, specifically SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are safe to use in patients with renal failure. These microbubbles are filled with gas and are excreted via the lungs rather than the kidneys, making them suitable for patients with compromised renal function. Unlike other contrast agents, USG contrast agents do not rely on renal clearance, thereby avoiding the risk of further renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI contrast agents (Gadolinium-based): These agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, a serious condition affecting the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Iodinated contrast: Commonly used in CT imaging, these agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, which can further impair renal function.

 

Option D. CT contrast agent: Typically, iodinated contrast is used in CT imaging, which is not safe for patients with renal failure for the reasons mentioned above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

USG contrast agents, such as SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are the only contrast agents safe for use in patients with renal failure as they are excreted via the lungs and do not rely on renal clearance.

questions.text: Maximum absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria occurs in the: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Colon

 

Explanation:

 

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are primarily produced in the colon and absorbed from it. These 2-5 carbon weak acids have an average concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the colonic lumen, with acetate (60%), propionate (25%), and butyrate (15%) being the predominant types. They form through bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber components that escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs.
  • Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here.
  • Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCFAs are unique among fatty acids in that they're produced by bacterial fermentation in the colon and represent an important source of energy for colonic epithelial cells, helping maintain mucosal integrity and acid-base balance.

questions.text: Home based urine pregnancy tests detect which hormone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

Home-based urine pregnancy tests detect human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), specifically the beta subunit of hCG (β-hCG).

 

  • hCG is the earliest detectable hormone in pregnancy
  • hCG is secreted by the trophoblastic cells of the developing placenta soon after implantation, which occurs approximately 6-10 days post-fertilization.
  • The hormone helps maintain the corpus luteum, ensuring continued progesterone production to support early pregnancy.
  • Urine pregnancy tests typically detect hCG levels at or above 20-25 mIU/mL, allowing for early pregnancy confirmation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): This is a pituitary hormone involved in follicular development and not specific to pregnancy. It is not used for pregnancy detection as its levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

 

Option C. Estrogen: While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, it is not specific enough for pregnancy detection as it is also present during normal menstrual cycles.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Although progesterone levels rise during pregnancy, it is not used in home pregnancy tests as it is also present during the luteal phase of menstrual cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Home pregnancy tests specifically detect the beta subunit of hCG in urine for pregnancy diagnosis.
